title: Two Step Cliffs
text: Two Step Cliffs () is the eastern face of a flat-topped sedimentary <a href="mountain">mountain</a>, rising to about 680 m, immediately east of <a href="Mars%20Glacier">Mars Glacier</a> on the east coast of <a href="Alexander%20Island">Alexander Island</a>, <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>. At the bottom of the cliffs is the <a href="Two%20Step%20Moraine">Two Step Moraine</a>. First seen from the air by <a href="Lincoln%20Ellsworth">Lincoln Ellsworth</a> on November 23, 1935, and mapped from photos obtained on that flight by <a href="W.L.G.%20Joerg">W.L.G. Joerg</a>. Roughly surveyed from the ground in 1936 by the <a href="British%20Graham%20Land%20Expedition">British Graham Land Expedition</a> and in 1940-41 by the <a href="United%20States%20Antarctic%20Service">United States Antarctic Service</a>, who used the names "Two Step Mountains" and "Table Mountain" for this feature. The name Two Step Cliffs derives from the name used by USAS, and was suggested by <a href="Falkland%20Islands%20Dependencies%20Survey">Falkland Islands Dependencies Survey</a> following surveys in 1949 as being particularly descriptive of this feature.
